title: How to Make Beef Tallow in a Slow Cooker or on the Stove

steps.title: Chop 3 lb (1.4 kg) of beef trimmings into chunks and put them in a slow cooker.
steps.content: Chop 3 lb (1.4 kg) of beef trimmings into chunks and put them in a slow cooker. Leave the lid off the slow cooker to allow any excess liquid to evaporate into the air. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Turn the slow cooker on low for 6-8 hours.
steps.content: Turn the slow cooker on low for 6-8 hours. Let it come to a simmer, but never a boil. Stir occasionally to remove any pieces of fat or beef from the bottom of the slow cooker before it sticks and burns. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Turn off the heat when the liquid fat is clear and half the solid fat is brown.
steps.content: Turn off the heat when the liquid fat is clear and half the solid fat is brown. Don't let any of the solid fat turn black or the liquid fat get too brown or orange, or it will have an almost burnt flavor and smell. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Line a fine mesh strainer with cheesecloth and strain the tallow through it.
steps.content: Line a fine mesh strainer with cheesecloth and strain the tallow through it. The liquid tallow will filter through the cheesecloth and the fine mesh strainer into the bowl, while the cheesecloth will catch any remaining pieces of solid fat and beef. [4] X Research source It's important to strain any remaining beef from the tallow to prevent the tallow from going rancid too soon after it's been stored.

steps.title: Pour the liquid tallow into a glass container with an airtight lid.
steps.content: Pour the liquid tallow into a glass container with an airtight lid. Let it cool and solidify thoroughly before screwing the lid on the container. Then store the tallow in a cool, dry place, such as your refrigerator. [5] X Research source Wide-mouth glass mason jars work best, since they're easier to scrape tallow out of once it's solidified.

steps.title: Chop 3 lb (1.4 kg) beef trimmings into small pieces.
steps.content: Chop 3 lb (1.4 kg) beef trimmings into small pieces. Refrigerate the trimmings beforehand to make them easier to cut. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Heat the beef trimmings on low in a large pot on the stove for 5-6 hours.
steps.content: Heat the beef trimmings on low in a large pot on the stove for 5-6 hours. Stir the beef trimmings periodically. Remember to scrape the bottom of the pot to prevent pieces of beef or beef fat from sticking to it and burning. [7] X Research source

steps.title: When the fat is liquefied with brown cracklings floating on top, it's done.
steps.content: When the fat is liquefied with brown cracklings floating on top, it's done. Remove the tallow from the heat before it browns or burns and let it cool for a few minutes. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Strain the beef tallow through cheesecloth over a fine mesh strainer.
steps.content: Strain the beef tallow through cheesecloth over a fine mesh strainer. Ensure the liquid tallow is completely free of any pieces of beef and solid fat. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Transfer the liquid tallow into an airtight glass container.
steps.content: Transfer the liquid tallow into an airtight glass container. Allow it to cool thoroughly before putting the lid on the container and storing it in your refrigerator. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Gather your tallow soap ingredients and supplies.
steps.content: Gather your tallow soap ingredients and supplies. This basic beef tallow soap recipe only requires three ingredients, but you'll also need protective gear and several cooking utensils. We have everything you need listed below. [11] X Research source 30 fl oz (890 mL) liquid tallow 3.88 oz (110 g) lye (sodium hydroxide) 11 fl oz (330 mL) distilled water White vinegar to neutralize lye that comes in contact with your skin Goggles, face mask, long-sleeved shirt, and gloves Measuring cup 3 bowls and 1 pan Wax paper Soap mold and bar cutter Digital kitchen thermometer Digital kitchen scale Immersion blender Wooden spoons

steps.title: Pour 11 fl oz (330 mL) water into a bowl and slowly stir 3.88 oz (110 g) lye into it.
steps.content: Pour 11 fl oz (330 mL) water into a bowl and slowly stir 3.88 oz (110 g) lye into it. Complete this step outside or turn on your kitchen vent hood to help waft away the lye fumes. Once the mixture is complete, let it cool to 100–110 °F (38–43 °C). [12] X Research source Avoid pouring water onto the lye, as this will cause the two substances to react too quickly and result in a miniature explosion. Wear your goggles, mask, long-sleeved shirt, and gloves while mixing the lye with the water. Not only are the fumes toxic, but lye is caustic and will burn your skin if it gets on you. If lye comes into contact with your skin, pour distilled vinegar on it to neutralize it.

steps.title: Heat 30 fl oz (890 mL) tallow in a pot on the stove on low until it reaches 100 °F (38 °C).
steps.content: Heat 30 fl oz (890 mL) tallow in a pot on the stove on low until it reaches 100 °F (38 °C). Then remove it from the heat and pour the lye and water mixture into it. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Blend the tallow and lye mixture with an immersion blender until it resembles pudding.
steps.content: Blend the tallow and lye mixture with an immersion blender until it resembles pudding. [14] X Research source At this point, you can add up to 50 drops of your favorite essential oil (optional). You can also leave it unscented if you prefer or are allergic to essential oil . [15] X Research source Use only high-quality essential oil, as it is the safest for your skin and overall health. Brands that sell pure essential oil will list the oil as the only ingredient (usually by its Latin name) and the process they used to extract it. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Line the soap mold with wax paper and pour the tallow into it.
steps.content: Line the soap mold with wax paper and pour the tallow into it. Wear your gloves during this step to protect your hands from the hot mixture. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Cover the mold and let the soap set for 2 days until it's solidified.
steps.content: Cover the mold and let the soap set for 2 days until it's solidified. It should be firm enough that you can cut into it with a knife, and the knife will come out clean. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the soap from the mold and cut it into squares using a soap-cutting tool.
steps.content: Remove the soap from the mold and cut it into squares using a soap-cutting tool. You can use a straight or wavy cutter to create a rippled texture on either side of each soap bar. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Set the bars on a piece of wax paper to "cure" – dry out – for 6 weeks.
steps.content: Set the bars on a piece of wax paper to "cure" – dry out – for 6 weeks. This step allows the excess moisture in the soap bars to evaporate, leaving the bars completely solid and ready for use. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Wrap the individual soap bars in wax paper to store them until use.
steps.content: Wrap the individual soap bars in wax paper to store them until use. You can store them in a cool, dry place until you're ready to use them, or you can give bars away to friends, family members, and coworkers. According to Shelley Williams, soapmaking expert and founder of Craft and Light , storing your tallow soap bars in wax paper helps protect their texture and maintain the oils and fats inside them.

steps.title: Cook, fry, and bake with tallow.
steps.content: Cook, fry, and bake with tallow. Beef tallow has a mild flavor and a high smoke point, both of which make it an excellent oil to use when you create all sorts of delicious meals. Swap butter and oil for tallow in these tasty recipes: Steak Fried chicken Vanilla, chocolate, or apple cake

steps.title: Make hydrating tallow body cream.
steps.content: Make hydrating tallow body cream. Whip tallow with a hand mixer until it's soft and aerated to create a body cream you can apply to your skin. You can also add other ingredients like essential oils, Vitamin E, and jojoba oil to make it smell better and make it more nourishing. [21] X Research source Tallow naturally contains conjugated linoleic acid (CLA), a type of fat that has anti-inflammatory properties. When applied to your skin, CLA and other vitamins in the tallow provide hydration and may improve your skin's elasticity. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Make an all-natural, moisturizing tallow lip balm.
steps.content: Make an all-natural, moisturizing tallow lip balm. Melt beef tallow with beeswax and add optional ingredients like Vitamin E and non-phototoxic essential oils. Pour the mixture into lip balm containers and allow the balm to cool and solidify before applying it to your lips. [23] X Research source Avoid phototoxic essential oils like orange, lemon, and Litsea cubeba. These oils can severely irritate your skin when they're exposed to sunlight, as they would be if you incorporated them into a tallow lip balm or body butter. [24] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Homemade beef tallow stays good for up to 1 year at room temperature.
steps.content: Homemade beef tallow stays good for up to 1 year at room temperature. You can also store it in the fridge for 12-18 months and in the freezer for up to 2 years if you don't plan on using it all right away. [25] X Research source You'll know your tallow has gone bad when it develops a sour, rancid smell and taste, at which point you should throw it out and make a new batch. [26] X Research source
